unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Find $H_{a}$
question_text: Which of the following is an alternative hypothesis for a chi-square test of independence?

choices.text: $H_{a}$: There is no association between two categorical variables in a given population
$H_{a}$: There is a difference in distributions of a categorical variable across populations.
$H_{a}$: Two categorical variables in a population are associated.
$H_{a}$: At least one of the given proportions is not equal to what is specified in the null hypothesis.
$H_{a}$: There is no difference in distributions of a categorical variable across populations.

solution:
Solution

The chi-square test for independence looks to see if two categorical variables are related.

The null hypothesis for this test assumes that there is no association or relationship between the two categorical variables; that is, the two variables are independent.

The alternative hypothesis for this test assumes that there is an association or relationship between the two categorical variables; that is, the two variables are dependent.

So, Choice 'C' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect because this is the null hypothesis for the chi-square test for independence.

Choice 'B' is incorrect because this is the alternative hypothesis for the chi-square test for homogeneity.

Choice 'D' is incorrect because this is the alternative hypothesis for the chi-square test for goodness of fit.

Choice 'E' is incorrect because this is the null hypothesis for the chi-square test for homogeneity.
